text: Brilliant! The intro is, as the one before, a work of art in itself. Still complex enough with drama, suspense, twists and heaps of action. Fast moving and very engaging. Very good cinematography and brought to screen in a admirable fashion. Intelligently written and whole cast succeeds in character, very convincingly.
Should have been a David Fincher direct sequel to the original 2011 film. Not this.

I don't want to compare it to the previous movies about it.
But having read all the books I'm not gonna say anything bad about this.its supposed to be fun.it touches on her abuse and shows her skills.

Story is everything and your telling me now that Lisbeth Salander has a twin sister who runs a criminal organization who is now framing Lisbeth who is already famous as a murderer.......if you never saw previous films you will love this film and if you saw the others you will be like me and wish they never made this film.......we went from realistic franchise to a modern superhero franchise.
Incomprehensible sequel to The Girl Who etc movies. Not quite good enough to be unbelievable. Lots of better stuff like this formula.

What a waste of 2hours of a movie well funded but very poorly written. I cannot understand how the main protagonist was built to be smart but very foolish at the same time. Letting a prisoner escape from airport security in a very detailed manner and at the same time bringing just taser in attempt to rescue the kid. Come on! I was furious the whole 2 hours because until the end I could not figure out how she didn't die already from the beginning for how stupid she is.

All in all. Effects brought the whole story. Everything else was complete trash and waste of time!

I love Fede Alvarez's work, but this is easily the worst "Millennium" adaptation to date, forgoing an intelligent script & characterizations for an action-heavy thriller that ends up being serviceable at best. Claire Foy is a solid Lisbeth though, & Sylvia Hoeks is underappreciated.

This is purely an action movie with a female lead. Claire Foy is a good actress. But there is very little dialog in this film. And what there is isn't said well. Its okay though. Nice rainy day movie.

Slick production with great camera work and colour. The story was passable, though leaning towards cliché with a lot of plot conveniences. I think the movie really fell down with its clipped dialogue that was trying to be a bit too clever for its own good. I'm sure it read well on paper. The acting was pretty stiff too - maybe that was the vibe the director was going for.
A miss mash mess. Just nothing works.  The only thing that works is the cinematography. Its good but even that ends up an inconsistent jumble.
A little surprising to these bad reviews.  Certainly far from a masterpiece, I felt entertained.  This is an action movie, so don't expect plausibility or perfect character development.

The Girl in the Spider Web (GSW) comes as an uninvited guest some 7 years after the David Fincher's The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, adding confusion to the storyline. A real shame considering Fede Alvarez's work in Don't Breathe (2016) and Evil Dead (2013).
 
GSW uses David Lagercrantz's homonymous work as source material, of which I know little about as I haven't read the books yet.
 
In this entry, Lisbeth Salander has to steal a might computerized weapon, highly visioned by a number of Orgs and criminals, while also dealing with her past that seems to want to hunt her to death, quite literally. If you have come from the Hollywood-targeted The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011), you will see familiar names, but no familiar faces — no recurring actors whatsoever.
 
I assume casting had to work on a budget, and hiring Daniel Craig was off; I wonder why they couldn't bring in Rooney Mara, because she did a way better Lisbeth than Claire Foy. Claire Foy is alright, but she lacks the heart and soul that Rooney put while playing Lisbeth's role.
 
Speaking of Daniel Craig, GSW's version of Mikael Blomkvist is too funny to go unnoticed. Actor Sverrir Gudnason gets his share of spotlight as a supporting character for Lisbeth, and I feel he was given the wrong directions. It feels Sverrir is trying to be seductive on all his shots, and that's f** annoying. It is funny to compare both Fincher's and Alvarez's Mikael with the Mikael from the Sweden version, which is far more mundane — perhaps too mundane.
 
GSW has a simplistic plot line, a line that is solid, but unexceptional. Remember that I haven't read the books, so I'm dismissing any comparisons. The fact is that this plot falls under good generic, it has all alright elements we expect, but compared to what we've saw on The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, the plot is far inferior. I feel the main reason is because the former had elements of a thriller, while GSW is more of a crime-action movie with a few stunts and predictable plot twists.
 
Tech elements are absent of commentary, I feel, at least for an amateur like myself. There are some slick shots, some humorous wannabe moments; the scenery is alright, but nothing spectacular. The soundtrack is a-okay. You can go brain-dead watching GSW and you would be fine.
 
And I feel this sums up the experience of watching GSW: brain dead. Do you know when you want to watch something light, shallow, not much thought process to expend, just watch beginning to end, go "yeah", and wrap up? That's GSW.
While this isn't my favorite of the franchise, it's well acted.  The plot isn't fully  developed, but the action is terrific.  Always great to see a female kick butt that deserves it.
Very watchable and convincingly done. Filmed closely to the book's plot which made it even more enjoyable to me.

So there's this program that can control the entirety of the nuclear arsenal worldwide.
It can be transferred over the internet in less than 60 seconds.
But nobody thought to make a backup of it.

As stunningly stupid a premise as that is, it's the smartest thing about this film.
Atrocious coincidences and technically incorrect moments drive a plot with less logic than the Bonzo Dog Doo Dah band's entire catalog.
A shameless attempt to keep making money off of a dead man, worst of all, it throws the characters you know and love entirely under the bus in the process.
Solid enough thriller without being memorable. The conversion of Lisbeth from anti-hero hacker to action star just doesn't quite payoff.
Great locations, rubbish generic story which just goes loosely from one action theme to another. Insult to the film Girl with the dragon tattoo, to call it a soft sequel.
Fincher and the original cast needed to return.

Adoro a franquia, agora sobre as mulheres que não amavam os homens, pois eram todos sádicos e nojentos… Agora na versão cibernética com direito a armas nucleares, muito bom todo clima de tensão e perseguição, no melhor estilo gato e rato, trama inteligente e bem delineada, Claire Foy muito bem como a Lisbeth Salander da vez...

I enjoyed the movie, but it strayed from the original.  Lisbeth's father was never a handsome man.  No mention of her mother.  The original didn't mention a sister.  In this movie, Lisbeth isn't merely a man hating lesbian, she's Tom Cruise protecting the world and she has a smaller team and less resources than Cruise.  Sweden is lucky to have such a fictional character.  8o)
